title: 106_s2617
content: The "Trade Normalization With Cuba Act" may be cited as the short title of this Act. The findings section highlights key points related to the Act. The Congress finds that the embargo on trade with Cuba is counterproductive and no longer necessary since Cuba is no longer a threat. The United States can support democratic change in Cuba through trade, commerce, travel, and communication. The United States can support democratic change in Cuba through promoting trade, commerce, travel, communication, and exchanges. SEC. 3. REMOVAL OF PROVISIONS RESTRICTING TRADE AND OTHER RELATIONS WITH CUBA. The authorities under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Trading With the Enemy Act regarding Cuba are repealed. Any export prohibitions to Cuba in effect before the effective date will be removed. On the effective date of this Act, export controls on Cuba under the Export Administration Act of 1979 will cease. The President can impose new export controls under various acts and exercise emergency powers due to a new threat to national security, foreign policy, or the economy. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 are repealed, including related amendments to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 are repealed, along with amendments to various sections of different acts. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996, along with amendments to various sections of different acts, are repealed. Additionally, Section 902(c) of the Food Security Act of 1985 is repealed, and a new provision exempts Cuba from certain regulations after 60 days from enactment. SEC. 4 authorizes common carriers to install, maintain, and repair telecommunications equipment in Cuba and provide services between the US and Cuba, including upgrades. SEC. 5 pertains to travel. SEC. 5 allows travel to and from Cuba for US citizens without regulation. Transactions related to travel, including banking transactions, are also permitted. SEC. 6 mandates the US Postal Service to establish direct mail service with Cuba. The President should conduct negotiations with Cuba to settle US nationals' property claims and protect human rights. The terms "national of the United States" and "property" are defined in the International Claims Settlement Act of 1949. This Act will take effect 60 days after enactment.
